channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Protests Today Live: News Updates and Video
item.description: The president spoke from a White House beset by protesters as another night of intense anger swept across cities constrained by curfews and patrolled by National Guard troops.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside the White House, where President Trump called violent demonstrations in American cities “domestic terrorism.”

item.title: How Minneapolis, One of America’s Most Liberal Cities, Struggles With Racism
item.description: The Midwestern city that has been the site of unrest views itself as embracing multiculturalism. But it also struggles with segregation and racial gaps on education.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers helped clear water on Saturday after a Wells Fargo bank was destroyed the night before during protests in Minneapolis.

item.title: As Coronavirus Toll Preoccupies U.S., Rivals Test Limits of American Power
item.description: The coronavirus may have changed almost everything, but it didn’t change this: Global competition spins ahead — and in many ways has accelerated.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Australia Department Of Defence, via Reuters
item.media:description: The amphibious assault ship America conducted maneuvers with other Australian and U.S. Navy vessels in the South China Sea in April, one of four such operations this year.

item.title: Is America’s Pandemic Waning or Raging? Yes
item.description: A single day reveals divergent realities across the country: As cases drop in the Northeast and some cities reopen, other places report stubbornly high numbers.
item.dc:creator: Julie Bosman and Mitch Smith
item.media:credit: Lyndon French for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chicago has been shuttered since March, with little hope that life in America’s third-largest city will return to normal soon.

item.title: After George Floyd’s Death, Toll Rises in Protests Across the Country
item.description: At least five people have died in unrest over the death of Mr. Floyd. Injuries have been numerous, and millions of dollars in damage to property has occurred.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson, Rick Rojas and Kate Taylor
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Odessa Riley, in red, the mother of David McAtee, the owner of a barbecue restaurant who was killed in an officer-involved shooting, approached the site of his death surrounded by family on Monday, in Louisville, Ky.

item.title: ‘Everybody Will Second-Guess’: Liberal Mayors Navigate Protesters and Police
item.description: For Democratic city leaders across the country, the unrest in their streets is testing their campaign promises and principles.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon and Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Nick Otto/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Mayor Michael Tubbs in his office in Stockton, Calif.

item.title: In Cities Battered by Protest, the Cleaning Crews Come Out
item.description: Many protesters have volunteered to clean up after looting and vandalism, in the hope that the movement will not be defined by destruction.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers swept up glass from vandalized and looted stores in Los Angeles on Sunday morning.

item.title: Trump Vowed to Disrupt Washington. Now He Faces Disruption in the Streets.
item.description: Washington’s elite has long bemoaned the “shattered norms” of the Trump presidency. But it has felt beside the point — like privilege talking — in the angry crowds of the last few nights.
item.dc:creator: Mark Leibovich
item.media:credit: Jonathan Ernst/Reuters
item.media:description: Protesters and the police outside the White House on Sunday.

item.title: U.S. Ruling Could Mean a Flood of New Claims Against Volkswagen
item.description: Judges on Monday cleared the way for counties to pursue the automaker, which has already paid more than $20 billion in federal penalties for cheating on pollution tests, under local laws.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:credit: Lucy Nicholson/Reuters
item.media:description: A Volkswagen lot near Victorville, Calif., in 2018, after the company agreed to buy back roughly 350,000 vehicles.

item.title: Matt Gaetz Tweet Gets Twitter Warning Label for Glorifying Violence
item.description: The post, from Representative Matt Gaetz, a Florida Republican, had likened protesters to terrorists and called for them to be hunted down.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Matt Gaetz, right, outside the West Wing in April.

item.title: Lawmakers Begin Bipartisan Push to Cut Off Police Access to Military-Style Gear
item.description: The effort to end a program transferring surplus military equipment from the Pentagon to the police reflects a revived bipartisan concern about excessive use of force by law enforcement.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers using a military-style vehicle confronted protesters in Santa Monica, Calif., on Sunday.

item.title: Trump and Putin Discuss Russia’s Attendance at G7, but Allies Are Wary
item.description: The British and Canadian governments oppose admitting Russia into the bloc, as President Trump continues a renewed courtship of Russia’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during the G20 summit in Osaka, Japan, last year.

item.title: They Fled Asia as Refugees. Now They Are Caught in the Middle of Minneapolis.
item.description: Thousands of Hmong-Americans settled in the Twin Cities area after the Vietnam War. They became business owners, teachers and police officers.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gather at the site of the death of George Floyd in police custody in Minneapolis.

item.title: Judge Asks Court Not to ‘Short Circuit’ His Review of Flynn Case
item.description: A lawyer for the trial judge told an appeals court why he wanted to examine the Justice Department’s “unusual” request to dismiss the charge.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Susan Walsh/Associated Press
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, had twice pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I. about his conversations with a Russian diplomat.

item.title: Misinformation About George Floyd Protests Surges on Social Media
item.description: In the universe of false online information, Mr. Floyd remains alive and George Soros is to blame for the protests.
item.dc:creator: Davey Alba
item.media:credit: Caroline Yang for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural of George Floyd at the site of his deadly arrest in Minneapolis. False information related to his death is spreading online.

item.title: Everyone Is Mad at Virgil Abloh Over the George Floyd Protests
item.description: The Off-White and Louis Vuitton designer has become a target of social media anger and frustration because of statements about the protests.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman and Elizabeth Paton
item.media:credit: David Kasnic for The New York Times
item.media:description: Virgil Abloh

item.title: Inside a Huge George Floyd Protest in Brooklyn
item.description: A demonstration that began at the Barclays Center drew New Yorkers from many backgrounds. They worried that their goals were being hijacked by looting and violence.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wilson
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man stood on the roof of his car in Brooklyn to urge on protesters marching near the Barclays Center.

item.title: Retailers, Battered by Coronavirus, Now Confront Protesters
item.description: Even as major chains boarded up stores and halted operations, they largely sought to convey empathy for demonstrators and did not condemn the damage to their businesses.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari and Michael Corkery
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: An employee at the Lone Wolf Cigar Company in Santa Monica, Calif., surveyed the damage done to the store by looters on Sunday.

item.title: Mass Extinctions Are Accelerating, Scientists Report
item.description: Five hundred species are likely to become extinct over the next two decades, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A farmer walked through a burned area of Amazon rainforest near Porto Velho, Brazil, last year.

item.title: How Did George Floyd Die? A Private Autopsy Said It Was Asphyxiation
item.description: A private autopsy commissioned by the family concluded that his death was a homicide, brought about by compression of his neck and back by Minneapolis police officers.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles and Audra D. S. Burch
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Terrence Floyd visits the site where his brother George Floyd was detained by the Minneapolis police last week. George Floyd’s death was ruled a homicide by a family autopsy.

item.title: E.P.A. Limits States’ Power to Oppose Pipelines and Other Energy Projects
item.description: The agency tweaked the rules on how to apply the Clean Water Act, which New York and other states have used to fight fossil-fuel ventures.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Al Drago
item.media:description: Andrew Wheeler, the Environmental Protection Agency head, said the administration was moving to “curb abuses of the Clean Water Act.”

item.title: Netanyahu’s Annexation Plans Meet Surprise Opponent: Israeli Settlers
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has promised to annex much of the occupied West Bank. But now that he can, there are questions about whether he will.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Israeli settlement of Ariel in the West Bank. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is suddenly facing resistance to annexation from settler leaders who have been agitating for it for years.

item.title: Joe Biden Listens to Anguish at a Black Church in Wilmington
item.description: After weeks of virtual events, Mr. Biden went to Bethel A.M.E. Church in Wilmington to hear from community leaders.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joe Biden prays with Representative Lisa Blunt Rochester (wearing a red mask) and community leaders at Bethel A.M.E. Church in Wilmington, Del.

item.title: Protests Spur Surge in Donations, Giving ActBlue Its Biggest Day of the Year
item.description: With money flowing to candidates, bail funds and charities, the Democrats’ online donor platform processed over $60 million between Friday and Monday, a sign of strength for the party.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters chanted slogans as they confronted the police in Santa Monica, Calif., on Sunday.

item.title: Trump's Governor Call: Full Audio [Listen]
item.description: In a Rose Garden speech shaded with anger, President Trump threatened to send the American military to states where governors could not bring the protests over police brutality under control.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers, Jonathan Martin and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesting outside the Minnesota Governor’s Residence in Minneapolis on Monday.

item.title: America, Inflamed. Join Us for a Special Conversation About Race.
item.description: Three New York Times national correspondents who have been reporting from the front lines will provide their insights.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters were detained by the police in Minneapolis on Sunday.

item.title: Supreme Court Upholds Federal Response to Puerto Rico Debt
item.description: The case concerned the constitutionality of appointments to a government board charged with restructuring billions of dollars of debt.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Puerto Rico’s debt crisis worsened after Hurricane Maria destroyed much of the island’s infrastructure in 2017.

item.title: Facebook Employees Stage Virtual Walkout to Protest Trump Posts
item.description: While Twitter started labeling some of the president’s inflammatory messages, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, has said his company should leave them alone.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel, Mike Isaac, Cecilia Kang and Gabriel J.X. Dance
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dozens of Facebook employees suddenly took the day off on Monday, requesting time to support demonstrators around the country.

item.title: How a Minnesota Bail Fund Raised $20 Million to Help Jailed Protestors
item.description: After the killing of George Floyd, a small Minneapolis fund that is paying bail for protesters saw a huge influx of donations.
item.dc:creator: Jonah Engel Bromwich
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mural of George Floyd in Minneapolis. Since his death last week, the Minnesota Freedom Fund, which posts bail for low-income people and protesters, has seen an outpouring of donations.

item.title: Protests in California Follow the Death of George Floyd
item.description: Monday: Snapshots from a chaotic weekend across the state.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters sat in the middle of Beverly Boulevard in the Fairfax district of Los Angeles on Saturday.

item.title: The Nation Seethes, and Trump’s Response Follows a Pattern
item.description: Mass protests denounce racial inequality and police violence: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: ‘The Minnesota Paradox’
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in front of the 5th Precinct in Minneapolis on Saturday.

item.title: View Pictures of the George Floyd Protests Nationwide
item.description: George Floyd’s death continued to resonate far beyond Minneapolis, where he died. In Boston, Philadelphia, New York, Ferguson, Mo., Portland, Ore., Los Angeles and countless other cities, demonstrations raged.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Biden Slowly Emerges From Seclusion, Hoping to Meet the Moment
item.description: Joseph Biden is showing that well-timed appearances from quarantine can be effective and powerful, though the dangers of a low profile are likely to escalate.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. on Memorial Day after laying a wreath at a veterans’ memorial in Delaware.

item.title: Biden Names Two New Advisers as Convention Decision Looms
item.description: The former vice president has enlisted two veteran strategists, including Senator Cory Booker’s former campaign manager, to help design a nominating convention under extraordinarily difficult circumstances.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Burns
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former Vice President Jospeh R. Biden Jr. at a town hall in Waukee, Iowa, in January.

item.title: Campaign Funds for Judges Warp Criminal Justice, Study Finds
item.description: Judges in Harris County, Texas, were far more likely to appoint lawyers who had donated to their campaigns to represent poor criminal defendants.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak
item.media:credit: Juan Lozano/Associated Press
item.media:description: A study examining campaign finance and the right to counsel focused on data from Harris County, Texas, the third most populous county in the nation.

item.title: States Warn That Virus May Doom Climate Projects
item.description: A billion-dollar program to protect cities from climate change is at risk of failing because of the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: Steve Helber/Associated Press
item.media:description: Rising waters, wind and rain as Hurricane Sandy approached Norfolk in 2012.

item.title: Live Stock Market News During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: Global Anger Grows Over George Floyd Death, and Becomes an Anti-Trump Cudgel
item.description: Public outcries over racism in the United States erupted from Addis Ababa to Vancouver. China and Iran, criticized on human rights by the Trump administration, called the killing of Mr. Floyd a symbol of American hypocrisy.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators marched in Berlin on Sunday to protest the death of George Floyd at the hands of police in Minneapolis.

item.title: Coronavirus News: Live Updates
item.description: “You see mass gatherings that could potentially be infecting hundreds and hundreds of people after everything we have done,” New York’s governor said. Hong Kong has banned an annual Tiananmen Square vigil, citing the virus.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protests in Manhattan on Sunday.

item.title: 8 Minutes and 46 Seconds: How George Floyd Was Killed in Police Custody [Video]
item.description: The Times has reconstructed the death of George Floyd on May 25. Security footage, witness videos and official documents show how a series of actions by officers turned fatal.
item.dc:creator: Evan Hill, Ainara Tiefenthäler, Christiaan Triebert, Drew Jordan, Haley Willis and Robin Stein

item.title: 8 Minutes and 46 Seconds: How George Floyd Was Killed in Police Custody
item.description: The Times has reconstructed the death of George Floyd on May 25. Security footage, witness videos and official documents show how a series of actions by officers turned fatal. (This video contains scenes of graphic violence.)
item.dc:creator: Evan Hill, Ainara Tiefenthäler, Christiaan Triebert, Drew Jordan, Haley Willis and Robin Stein

item.title: New York’s Days of Protest: What It Looked Like From the Streets
item.description: These are our most striking photos from five days of protest where crowds of demonstrators stopped traffic and clashed with police.
item.dc:creator: David Gonzalez
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: At a vigil in Sheridan Square in Manhattan, protesters read the names of black and trans people killed by the police.

item.title: Michigan Sheriff Took Off His Helmet and Marched With Protesters
item.description: Sheriff Christopher R. Swanson of Genesee County walked with demonstrators protesting police brutality and the death of George Floyd.
item.dc:creator: Mariel Padilla
